WASHINGTON The need for
better In school guidance of min
GRITTY youth will be the subject
of Delta Sigma Theta's fifth
Conference of Counselors," to
be held on Dec. 4 and S at the
University of North Carolina at
Greensboro, NC.


1.-The aspirational levels of
Negro youth can be raised by
better guidance and counselling."
said DR.. Geraldine P. Woods
of Los Angeles, national pres
ident of the women S public SER
vice organization, in announcing
plans for the regional meeting
of school administrators, guild
ance counselors, homeroom
teachers and social workers.
Results of the latest research
will be pre- ented to the partic
ipants. she said, "to acquaint
them with the background infor-
nation, the skills practices and
techniques necessary for the sue
cessful counseling of minority
youth in a locale affected by
changing social patterns"

with ma ster of ceremonies of
the evening disk jockey Jim
Spero.


From 500 to 100 experts in the
field from rehabilitation facili-
ties throughout the United States
and Canada are expected.


Chairmen and keynoters for
the three general sessions Of the
workshop are: Mary Switzer,
Commit ssioner of Vocational Re-
Mobilization Association, Depart
ment of Health, Education and
Welfare, Wa shington. DC: DR..
Frank H. Krusen, Temple Uni
versity Hospital and Jack Taylor
of the New York Times.

CARTOONIsT DITzEN TO APPEAR


AT REHABILITATION CONFAB

Walt Ditzen, the dean of Amer
lea s sports cartoonists, will ap-
pear S the keynote speaker at the
Association of Rehabilitation
Center annual banquet on the
tevening of December 2 at the
Westward Ho Hotel.


Ditzen' s appearance was an
nounced by Mrs. Monica Baird,
hospitality hostess for the asso-
ciation' s 5-day workshop to be
held at the Hiway House Novem-
Der %.


The cartoonist will augment his
pre- sentation with one Of his fam
Gus chalk talks. Ditzen will team

disappointment for the very ones
you seek to protect.


So, at your earliest convenience, get
together with an Arizona attorney
and the Trust Officers of the Valley
Bank to review your Will and to
revise it. Make certain you are
giving your family complete protec-
ton, taking advantage of worth
while tax savings and insuring the
distribution of your estate exactly
as you wish. Call any Valley Banker
for an appointment.

Wills that won't accomplish
their original purpose.


aren't worth the paper they are written on!

The old saw goes; Nothing is Ger
tain but death and taxes!" But
times change, too; that's for certain!
So it stands to reason that a Will
written years ago, perhaps in
another state, tailored to different
laws and tax regulations may have
reflected your desires for your
family at that time but is totally
inadequate nowl
Inadequate is a polite word for it.
The hard fact is that an out-of-date
Will can mean heartache and bitter

10th Avenue. Police said six
shots were fired.


Brown was ARE sted at 10th
Avenue and Buckeye Road by Pa
trolman Ralph Giordano 80
minutes after the shooting. Of
ficers said Brown told them he
had argued with Clinton earlier,
and that Clinton had threatened
him.

A charge of murder was filed
yesterday against a man accused
Of the gunshot Staying Of Willie
Clinton, 40, of 1913 w. Papago.


Police said Wilbert Brown, So,
of 1920 w. Yuma, admitted
shooting Clinton once 1.-THE chest
with a .38 caliber revolver when
Clinton stepped from a car in
in the 1900 block of S.

Experts state that it is safe to
wash vanished surfaces repeat
eddy, using soap or detergent suds
followed by rinse-wiping.

There are hundreds of ways
of making money!" remarked a
friend to the financier," But only
one honest one.''


'And what is thatT' jeeredt the
financier.


"Ah, hal" rejoined the first.
81 thought you wouldn't nowl"

Denzil Solomon, IL, seventh
grader at Booker T. Wa shingron
School, carefully removes his
wooden mobile creation which
was exhibited at the Phoenix
Art Museum.


He is the son of MIR. and
Mrs. Sam Solomon, 2438 W. JEFF
ferSon. Photo Bobby Heard
